section.heading: Modified program of industrial insurance for offenders engaged in work program directed by administrator of county or city jail or other local detention facility.

content.p: Any offender confined in a county jail, city jail or other local detention facility, while engaged in work in a work program directed by the administrator of the jail or other detention facility, whether the work program is operated by contract with a public entity or by a private employer, may receive coverage under the modified program of industrial insurance established by regulations adopted by the Division if the administrator of the jail or other detention facility complies with the provisions of the regulations and coverage is approved by a private carrier. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An offender is limited to the rights and remedies established by the provisions of the modified program of industrial insurance established by regulations adopted by the Division. The offender is not entitled to any rights and remedies established by the provisions ofchapters 616Ato617, inclusive, of NRS. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Division, in cooperation with the various administrators of jails and other detention facilities, shall adopt regulations setting forth a modified program of industrial insurance to provide offenders with industrial insurance against personal injuries arising out of and in the course of their work in a work program. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½administrator of the jail or other detention facilityï¿½ means the sheriff of a county jail, chief of police of a city jail or director of a local detention facility.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (Added to NRS by1997, 3347; A1999, 1717)—(Substituted in revision for NRS 616B.186)

section.heading: Policy of insurance: Required provisions in policies of private carriers; regulations of Commissioner concerning basic policy used by private carriers.

content.p: Must be in writing; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is subject tochapters 616Ato617, inclusive, of NRS and regulations adopted pursuant to those chapters; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If it contains a provision inconsistent with this chapter orchapter 616A,616C,616Dor617of NRS, shall be deemed to be reformed to conform with that chapter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Commissioner shall, by regulation, prescribe the basic policy to be used by private carriers.

section.heading: Policy of insurance: Coverage of all employees of employer; coverage of employees under consolidated insurance program.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, an insurer shall not issue a policy of industrial insurance to an employer that does not cover each employee of that employer who satisfies the definition of employee set forth inNRS 616A.105to616A.225, inclusive. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the employer is a contractor or subcontractor who is engaged in the construction of a project that is covered by a consolidated insurance program established pursuant toNRS 616B.710to616B.737, inclusive, an insurer may issue a policy of industrial insurance to that employer which does not cover an employee who: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is assigned to participate in the construction of the project that is covered by the consolidated insurance program; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Works exclusively at the site of the construction project that is covered by the consolidated insurance program.

section.heading: Policy of insurance: Coverage for domestic worker as part of homeownerï¿½s policy of insurance.

content.p: A private carrier may provide industrial insurance, as a part of a homeownerï¿½s policy of insurance, to a person who employs a domestic worker for the term of that workerï¿½s employment. Upon providing such coverage, the private carrier may, with the approval of the Commissioner, determine and fix the premium rates to be paid for the industrial insurance so provided. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A domestic worker for whom industrial insurance is provided pursuant to subsection 1: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Shall be deemed to be an employee while performing work for his or her employer at a wage: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Equal to his or her average monthly wage as determined pursuant to the regulations adopted by the Administrator pursuant toNRS 616C.420if the domestic worker is employed more than 20 hours per week; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Of $150 per month if the domestic worker is employed not more than 20 hours per week; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is entitled to the benefits ofchapters 616Ato616D, inclusive, of NRS. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Domestic workerï¿½ is a person who is engaged exclusively in household or domestic service performed inside or outside of a personï¿½s residence. The term includes, without limitation, a cook, housekeeper, maid, companion, babysitter, chauffeur or gardener. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

ï¿½Homeownerï¿½s policy of insuranceï¿½ means a policy of property or casualty insurance that provides coverage for the loss of or damage to a home or against liability for the death or injury of a person or damage to property.

section.heading: Default of employer does not relieve insurer from liability; effect of statements contained in application for policy; notification of employer of cancellation of policy; defense based on act or omission of insured employer may not be raised by insurer against claimant; insurer placed in position of employer under certain circumstances.

content.p: Every policy of insurance issued pursuant tochapters 616Ato617, inclusive, of NRS must contain a provision for the requirements of subsection 5 and a provision that insolvency or bankruptcy of the employer or the employerï¿½s estate, or discharge therein, or any default of the employer does not relieve the insurer from liability for compensation resulting from an injury otherwise covered under the policy issued by the insurer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

No statement in an employerï¿½s application for a policy of industrial insurance voids the policy as between the insurer and employer unless the statement is false and would have materially affected the acceptance of the risk if known by the insurer, but in no case does the invalidation of a policy as between the insurer and employer affect the insurerï¿½s obligation to provide compensation to claimants arising before the cancellation of the policy. If the insurer is required pursuant to this subsection to provide compensation under an invalid policy, the insurer is subrogated to the claimantï¿½s rights against the employer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If an insurer intends to cancel a policy of insurance issued by the insurer pursuant tochapters 616Ato617, inclusive, of NRS, the insurer must give notice to that effect in writing to the employer fixing the date on which it is proposed that the cancellation becomes effective, which must be at least 30 days after the date on which the notice is personally delivered or mailed to the employer, except in the case of cancellation for failure to pay a premium when due. The notices must comply with the provisions ofNRS 687B.310to687B.355, inclusive, and must be served personally on or sent by first-class mail or electronic transmission to the employer. If the employer has secured insurance with another insurer which would cause double coverage, the cancellation must be made effective as of the effective date of the other insurance. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As between any claimant and the insurer, no defense based on any act or omission of the insured employer, if different from the insurer, may be raised by the insurer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the purposes ofchapters 616Ato617, inclusive, of NRS, as between the employee and the insurer: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Jurisdiction over the employer is jurisdiction over the insurer; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The insurer is bound by and subject to any judgments, findings of fact, conclusions of law, awards, decrees, orders or decisions rendered against the employer in the same manner and to the same extent as the employer.

section.heading: Conditions for providing industrial insurance for organization or association of employers; approval of group or organization; adoption of regulations.

content.p: A private carrier may provide industrial insurance for an organization or association of employers as a group if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The members of the organization or association are engaged in a common trade or business; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The formation and operation of a program of industrial insurance for the organization or association will substantially assist in the handling of claims and the prevention of accidents for the employers as a group. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection 1, a private carrier may provide industrial insurance for an organization or association of employers as a group whose members are not engaged in a common trade or business if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The organization or association of employers is formed and maintained for purposes other than obtaining industrial insurance; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The contract or other agreement pursuant to which the private carrier will provide industrial insurance for the organization or association provides that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A separate policy will be issued to each member of the organization or association; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Other than the payment of premiums by the organization or association, the organization or association and each of its members are not liable for the cost of the administration of claims or the compensation payable pursuant to the provisions ofchapters 616Ato616D, inclusive, or chapter617of NRS. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Commissioner must approve each organization or association before a policy of industrial insurance may be issued to it as a group pursuant to subsection 1 or 2. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Commissioner shall adopt regulations for the qualification of organizations or associations of employers described in subsections 1 and 2.

section.heading: Prohibition against charging fee for inclusion on panel of providers of health care; penalty.

content.p: If an insurer establishes a panel of providers of health care for the purpose of offering health care services pursuant tochapters 616Ato617, inclusive, of NRS, the insurer shall not charge a provider of health care: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A fee to include the name of the provider on the panel of providers of health care; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any other fee related to establishing a provider of health care as a provider for the insurer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If an insurer violates the provisions of subsection 1, the insurer shall pay to the provider of health care an amount that is equal to twice the fee charged to the provider of health care. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A court shall award costs and reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees to the prevailing party in an action brought pursuant to this section.

section.heading: Creation; source; investments.

content.p: There is hereby established in the State Treasury the State Insurance Fund. The Commissioner shall administer the Fund. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The money in the Fund may be invested by the State Treasurer in accordance with the provisions ofNRS 355.140,355.150and355.160. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any money delivered to the Commissioner pursuant toNRS 616B.042and696B.360must be deposited in the Fund and be held in trust by the Commissioner as custodian thereof for the purpose of providing compensation for industrial accidents and occupational diseases and for administrative expenses incidental thereto.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (Added to NRS by1999, 1763)—(Substituted in revision for NRS 616B.0862)

section.heading: Money to provide compensation held in trust; conditions when trust money to be deposited in Fund.

content.p: The chief executive officer of any successor organization to the State Industrial Insurance System shall continue to hold in trust any money paid to the System for the purpose of providing compensation for industrial accidents and occupational diseases and administrative expenses incidental thereto. The successor organization shall use that money only for the purpose for which it was paid. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If any successor organization to the State Industrial Insurance System ceases to provide industrial insurance in this State, all money held in trust pursuant to subsection 1 must be delivered to the Commissioner on a date that ensures that all benefits will be paid to qualified claimants under policies of industrial insurance previously issued by the State Industrial Insurance System or the successor organization. The Commissioner shall deposit the money delivered to the Commissioner pursuant to this subsection in the State Insurance Fund.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (Added to NRS by1999, 1762)—(Substituted in revision for NRS 616B.0865)

section.heading: Authority of successor organization to take credit for reinsurance.

content.p: Any successor organization to the State Industrial Insurance System may take as credit as an asset or as a deduction from liability on account of reinsurance for reinsurance ceded to an assuming alien insurer with security based on discounted reserves for losses that were maintained by the System for accounting periods beginning before July 1, 1995, at a rate not to exceed 6 percent. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½alien insurerï¿½ has the meaning ascribed to it inNRS 679A.090.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (Added to NRS by1999, 1763)—(Substituted in revision for NRS 616B.0867)

section.heading: Disposition of money in Fund on repeal of statutes relating to workersï¿½ compensation.

content.p: Ifchapters 616Ato616D, inclusive, of NRS shall hereafter be repealed, all moneys which are in the State Insurance Fund at the time of the repeal shall be subject to such disposition as may be provided by the Legislature, and in default of such legislative provisions distribution thereof shall be in accordance with the justice of the matter, due regard being had to obligations of compensation incurred and existing.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ [98:168:1947; 1943 NCL ï¿½ 2680.98]—(NRS A1973, 604)—(Substituted in revision for NRS 616B.101)

section.heading: Appeal by principal contractor from denial of final certificate of coverage for project; appeal by employer from determination regarding vocational rehabilitation of injured employee.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A principal contractor or an owner of property acting as a principal contractor aggrieved by a letter issued pursuant toNRS 616B.645; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An employer aggrieved by a determination made pursuant toNRS 616C.585, ï¿½may appeal from the letter or determination by filing a notice of appeal with the Administrator within 30 days after the date of the letter or determination. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An employer shall not seek to remove costs that have been charged to the account of the employer by appealing to the Administrator any issue that relates to a claim for compensation if the issue was raised or could have been raised before a hearing officer or an appeals officer pursuant toNRS 616C.315or616C.345. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The decision of the Administrator is the final and binding administrative determination of an appeal filed pursuant to this section, and the whole record consists of all evidence taken at the hearing before the Administrator and any findings based thereon.

section.heading: Determination of total amount paid to employees for services performed during policy year.

content.p: To determine the total amount paid to employees for services performed, the maximum amount paid to any one employee during a policy year shall be deemed to be $36,000.

section.heading: Periodic report of payroll and reported tips; periodic payment of premiums; effect of failure to submit information or premiums; collection of premiums by insurer.

content.p: Every private or public employer who is not a self-insured employer or a member of an association of self-insured public or private employers shall, at intervals and on or before dates established by the employerï¿½s insurer, furnish the insurer with: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A true and accurate payroll showing: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The amount of tips reported to the employer by every employee pursuant to 26 U.S.C. ï¿½ 6053
whose tips in cash totaled $20 or more; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A segregation of employment in accordance with the requirements of the Commissioner; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any premium due pursuant to the terms of the policy of industrial insurance. ï¿½The payroll reports and any premium may be furnished to the insurer on different dates, as established by the insurer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The failure of any employer to comply with the provisions of this section operates as a rejection ofchapters 616Ato616D, inclusive, and chapter617of NRS. The insurer shall, within the period specified in subsection 2 ofNRS 616B.461, notify the Administrator of each such rejection by notifying the Administrator of its cancellation or decision not to renew the policy of that employer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The insurer shall notify any employer or the representative of the employer by first-class mail of any failure on his or her part to comply with the provisions of this section. The notice or its omission does not modify or waive the requirements or effective rejection ofchapters 616Ato616D, inclusive, and chapter617of NRS as otherwise provided in those chapters. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

To the extent permitted by federal law, the insurer shall vigorously pursue the collection of premiums that are due under the provisions ofchapters 616Ato616D, inclusive, and chapter617of NRS even if an employerï¿½s debts have been discharged in a bankruptcy proceeding.
Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, an employer shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Make a copy of each report that an employee files with the employer pursuant to 26 U.S.C. ï¿½ 6053
to report the amount of his or her tips to the United States Internal Revenue Service; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Submit the copy to his or her private carrier upon request and retain another copy for his or her records or, if the employer is self-insured or a member of an association of self-insured public or private employers, retain the copy for his or her records. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An employer who maintains his or her records concerning payroll by a computerized program or process that can produce a report on all employees which indicates: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The amount of tips reported by each employee pursuant to 26 U.S.C. ï¿½ 6053
; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The amount of tips allocated to each employee pursuant to a formula applied by the employer, whether by agreement of the employees or by imposition of the employer, ï¿½may satisfy the requirements of subsection 1 by submitting a copy of the report to his or her private carrier and maintaining another copy of the report for his or her records. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An employer who is not self-insured or a member of an association of self-insured public or private employers shall pay the private carrier the premiums for the reported tips at the same rate as he or she pays on regular wages. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The private carrier, self-insured employer or association of self-insured public or private employers shall calculate compensation for an employee on the basis of wages paid by the employer plus the amount of tips reported by the employee pursuant to 26 U.S.C. ï¿½ 6053
. Reports made after the date of injury may not be used for the calculation of compensation. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An employer shall notify his or her employees of the requirement to report income from tips to calculate his or her federal income tax and to include the income in the computation of benefits pursuant tochapters 616Ato616D, inclusive, and chapter617of NRS. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Administrator shall adopt such regulations as are necessary to carry out the provisions of this section.

section.heading: Budgeting for premiums and payment of premiums by public employers.

content.p: Every state office, department, board, commission, bureau, agency or institution, operating by authority of law, and each county, city, school district and other political subdivision of this State shall budget for industrial insurance in the same manner as for other expenses and, if insured by a private carrier, shall pay premiums as required by its contract.

An employer may qualify and remain qualified as a self-insured employer by establishing to the satisfaction of the Commissioner that the employer has sufficient administrative and financial resources to make certain the prompt payment of all compensation underchapters 616Ato616D, inclusive, or chapter617of NRS. For the purposes of this subsection, an employer has sufficient financial resources if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

At the time of initial qualification and until the employer has operated successfully as a qualified self-insured employer for 3 years, as determined by the Commissioner, the employer has a tangible net worth of not less than $2,500,000, as evidenced by a statement of tangible net worth provided to the Division of Insurance of the Department of Business and Industry by an independent certified public accountant; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

After 3 years of successful operation as a qualified self-insured employer, as determined by the Commissioner, the employer has net cash flows from operating activities plus net cash flows from financing activities of five times the average of claims paid for each of the last 3 years or $7,500,000, whichever is less. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A self-insured employer must, in addition to establishing financial ability to pay, deposit with the Commissioner a bond executed by the employer as principal, and by a corporation qualified under the laws of this State as surety, payable to the State of Nevada, and conditioned upon the payment of compensation for injuries and occupational diseases to employees. The bond must be in an amount reasonably sufficient to ensure payment of compensation, but in no event may it be less than 105 percent of the employerï¿½s expected annual incurred cost of claims, or less than $100,000. In arriving at an amount for the expected annual cost of claims, due consideration must be given to the past and prospective experience of the employer with losses and expenses within this State, to the hazard of catastrophic loss, to other contingencies, and to trends within the State. In arriving at the amount of the deposit required, the Commissioner may consider the nature of the employerï¿½s business, the financial ability of the employer to pay compensation and the employerï¿½s probable continuity of operation. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In lieu of a bond, the employer may deposit with the Commissioner a like amount of lawful money of the United States or any other form of security authorized byNRS 100.065. If security is provided in the form of a savings certificate, certificate of deposit or investment certificate, the certificate must state that the amount is unavailable for withdrawal except upon order of the Commissioner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The required deposit may be increased or decreased by the Commissioner in accordance withchapter 681Bof NRS and the Commissionerï¿½s regulations for loss reserves in casualty insurance. If the Commissioner requires an employer to increase his or her deposit, the Commissioner may specify the form of the additional security. The employer shall comply with such a requirement within 60 days after receiving notice from the Commissioner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Commissioner shall require the self-insured employer to submit evidence of excess insurance to provide protection against a catastrophic loss. The excess insurance must be written by an insurer authorized to do business in this State. The Commissioner shall consider the excess insurance coverage as a basis for a reduction in the deposit required of an employer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Account for Self-Insured Employers is hereby created in the State Agency Fund for Bonds. All money received by the Commissioner pursuant to this section must be deposited with the State Treasurer to the credit of the Account for Self-Insured Employers. All claims against this Account must be paid as other claims against the State are paid.

section.heading: Standard for insolvency.

content.p: For the purposes ofNRS 616B.306,616B.309and616B.318, an employer is insolvent if the employerï¿½s assets are less than the employerï¿½s liabilities.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (Added to NRS by1985, 582)—(Substituted in revision for NRS 616.2915)

section.heading: Commissioner may sell securities or institute proceedings on surety bonds of self-insured employer to pay claims.

content.p: If a self-insured employer becomes insolvent, institutes any voluntary proceeding under the Bankruptcy Act or is named in any involuntary proceeding thereunder, makes a general or special assignment for the benefit of creditors or fails to pay compensation underchapters 616Ato616D, inclusive, or chapter617of NRS after an order for payment of any claim becomes final, the Commissioner may, after giving at least 10 daysï¿½ notice to the employer and any insurer or guarantor, use money or interest on securities, sell securities or institute legal proceedings on surety bonds deposited or filed with the Commissioner pursuant toNRS 679B.175to the extent necessary to make those payments. Until the Commissioner gives a 10-day notice pursuant to this section, the employer is entitled to all interest and dividends on bonds or securities on deposit pursuant toNRS 679B.175and to exercise all voting rights, stock options and other similar incidents of ownership thereof.

section.heading: Assessment of self-insured employers to provide for claims against insolvent employers; Account for Insolvent Self-Insured Employers.

content.p: The Commissioner may assess all self-insured employers to provide for claims against any insolvent self-insured employer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

All money received from such assessments must be deposited with the State Treasurer to the credit of the Account for Insolvent Self-Insured Employers, which is hereby created in the Fund for Workersï¿½ Compensation and Safety. Money in the Account must be used solely to carry out the provisions of this section. All claims against the Account must be paid as other claims against the State are paid. The State Treasurer shall invest money in the account in the same manner and in the same securities in which the State Treasurer may invest money of the State General Fund. Income realized from the investment of the assets in the Account must be credited to the Account.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (Added to NRS by1985, 933; A1991, 1800)—(Substituted in revision for NRS 616.2925)

section.heading: Certificate of qualification as self-insured employer: Issuance by Commissioner; contents; effective date; period certificate is in effect.

content.p: Upon determining that an employer is qualified as a self-insured employer, the Commissioner shall issue a certificate to that effect to the employer and the Administrator. No certificate may be issued to any employer who, within the 2 years immediately preceding the employerï¿½s application, has had his or her certification as a self-insured employer involuntarily withdrawn by the Commissioner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A certificate issued pursuant to this section must include, without limitation: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The name of the self-insured employer; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An identification number assigned to the self-insured employer by the Commissioner; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The date on which the certificate was issued. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided inNRS 616B.315and616B.318, certificates issued pursuant to this section remain in effect until withdrawn by the Commissioner or cancelled by the employer. Coverage for employers qualifying underNRS 616B.615becomes effective on the date of certification or the date specified in the certificate.

section.heading: Notification of change in ownership or control of self-insured employer; automatic termination of certification unless extension granted.

content.p: A self-insured employer shall notify the Commissioner not less than 60 days before any change in ownership or control of the employer. The certification of the self-insured employer terminates automatically on the date of the change unless the Commissioner extends the certification. Except as otherwise provided inNRS 616B.015, the Commissioner, upon request, may declare as confidential any documents which are submitted in support of a request for such an extension. Documents declared confidential pursuant to this section are subject to the provisions ofNRS 239.0115.

section.heading: Grounds for withdrawal of certification of self-insured employer; exception; administrative fine.

content.p: The Commissioner shall impose an administrative fine, not to exceed $1,000 for each violation, and: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Shall withdraw the certification of a self-insured employer if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The deposit required pursuant toNRS 616B.300is not sufficient and the employer fails to increase the deposit after the employer has been ordered to do so by the Commissioner; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The self-insured employer fails to provide evidence of excess insurance pursuant toNRS 616B.300within 45 days after the employer has been so ordered; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided in subsection 4, the employer becomes insolvent, institutes any voluntary proceeding under the Bankruptcy Act or is named in any involuntary proceeding thereunder. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
May withdraw the certification of a self-insured employer if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The employer intentionally fails to comply with regulations of the Commissioner regarding reports or other requirements necessary to carry out the purposes ofchapters 616Ato616D, inclusive, and chapter617of NRS; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The employer violates the provisions of subsection 2 ofNRS 616B.500or any regulation adopted by the Commissioner or the Administrator concerning the administration of the employerï¿½s plan of self-insurance; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The employer makes a general or special assignment for the benefit of creditors or fails to pay compensation after an order for payment of any claim becomes final. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any employer whose certification as a self-insured employer is withdrawn must, on the effective date of the withdrawal, qualify as an employer pursuant toNRS 616B.650. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Commissioner may, upon the written request of an employer whose certification as a self-insured employer is withdrawn pursuant to subparagraph (3) of paragraph
of subsection 1, reinstate the employerï¿½s certificate for a reasonable period to allow the employer sufficient time to provide industrial insurance for his or her employees. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Commissioner may authorize an employer to retain his or her certification as a self-insured employer during the pendency of a proceeding specified in subparagraph (3) of paragraph
of subsection 1 if the employer establishes to the satisfaction of the Commissioner that the employer is able to pay all claims for compensation during the pendency of the proceeding.

section.heading: Imposition of fine if self-insured employer fails to pay compensation as ordered.

content.p: The Commissioner shall impose an administrative fine, not to exceed $5,000, if an employer whose certification as a self-insured employer has terminated fails to pay compensation pursuant tochapters 616Ato616D, inclusive, or chapter617of NRS after an order for payment of any claim becomes final.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (Added to NRS by1985, 582; A1991, 2404)—(Substituted in revision for NRS 616.2945)

section.heading: Self-insured employer liable for violation by employerï¿½s agent.

content.p: A person who is employed by or contracts with a self-insured employer to administer the plan of self-insurance is an agent of the self-insured employer, and if he or she violates any provision of this chapter orchapter 616A,616C,616Dor617of NRS, the self-insured employer is liable for any penalty assessed because of that violation.

section.heading: Withdrawal of certification of self-insured employer: Informal meeting; notice of withdrawal; hearing; effective date of withdrawal.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided inNRS 616D.120, before any action may be taken pursuant to subsection 2, the Commissioner of Insurance shall arrange an informal meeting with the self-insured employer to discuss and seek correction of any conduct which would be grounds for withdrawal of the self-insured employerï¿½s certificate of self-insurance. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided inNRS 616D.120, before the withdrawal of the certification of any self-insured employer, the Commissioner of Insurance shall give written notice to that employer by certified mail that the employerï¿½s certification will be withdrawn 10 days after receipt of the notice unless, within that time, the employer corrects the conduct set forth in the notice as the reason for the withdrawal or submits a written request for a hearing to the Commissioner of Insurance. Before requesting a hearing the employer must make the deposit required byNRS 616B.300. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the employer requests a hearing: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Commissioner of Insurance shall set a date for a hearing within 20 days after receiving the appeal request, and shall give the employer at least 10 business daysï¿½ notice of the time and place of the hearing. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A record of the hearing must be kept but it need not be transcribed unless requested by the employer with the cost of transcription to be charged to the employer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Within 5 business days after the hearing, the Commissioner of Insurance shall either affirm or disaffirm the withdrawal and give the employer written notice thereof by certified mail. If withdrawal of certification is affirmed, the withdrawal becomes effective 10 business days after the employer receives notice of the affirmance unless within that period of time the employer corrects the conduct which was ground for the withdrawal or petitions for judicial review of the affirmance. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the withdrawal of certification is affirmed following judicial review, the withdrawal becomes effective 5 days after entry of the final decree of affirmance.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (Added to NRS by1979, 1037; A1995, 1640)—(Substituted in revision for NRS 616.296)

section.heading: Self-insured employer may appeal decision of Commissioner.

content.p: Any self-insured employer who is aggrieved by a decision of the Commissioner of Insurance may appeal in the manner set forth inNRS 679B.310, except that any such appeal must be filed within the time set forth inNRS 616B.327.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (Added to NRS by1979, 1039)—(Substituted in revision for NRS 616.298)

section.heading: Disposition of security after termination of status as self-insured employer.

content.p: If for any reason the status of an employer as a self-insured employer is terminated, the security deposited underNRS 616B.300must remain on deposit for a period of at least 36 months in such amount as necessary to secure the outstanding and contingent liability arising from accidental injuries or occupational diseases secured by such security, or to assure the payment of claims for aggravation, payment of claims underNRS 616C.390and payment of claims underNRS 616C.392based on such accidental injuries or occupational diseases. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

At the expiration of the 36-month period, or such other period as the Commissioner deems proper, the Commissioner may accept, in lieu of any security so deposited, a policy of paid-up insurance in a form approved by the Commissioner.

section.heading: Self-insured employers to furnish annual financial statements to Commissioner; Commissioner may examine records and interview employees.

content.p: Each self-insured employer shall furnish financial statements audited by an independent certified public accountant, or foreign equivalent, to the Commissioner annually within 120 days after the expiration of the self-insured employerï¿½s fiscal year, or within such other time frame as the Commissioner may allow. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Commissioner may examine the records and interview the employees of each self-insured employer as often as the Commissioner deems advisable to determine the adequacy of the deposit which the employer has made with the Commissioner, the sufficiency of reserves and the reporting, handling and processing of injuries or claims. The Commissioner shall examine the records for that purpose at least once every 3 years. The self-insured employer shall reimburse the Commissioner for the cost of the examination.

section.heading: Qualification as association of self-insured public or private employers; application for certification; fee; confidentiality of financial information submitted for certification.

content.p: A group of five or more employers may not act as an association of self-insured public employers unless the group: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is composed of employers engaged in the same or similar classifications of employment; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has been issued a certificate to act as such an association by the Commissioner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A group of five or more employers may not act as an association of self-insured private employers unless each member of the group: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is a member or associate member of a bona fide trade association, as determined by the Commissioner, which: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is incorporated in this State; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has been in existence for at least 5 years; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has been issued a certificate to act as such an association by the Commissioner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An association of public or private employers that wishes to be issued a certificate must file with the Commissioner an application for certification. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The application must include: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The name of the association. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The address of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The principal office of the association. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The location where the books and records of the association will be maintained. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The date the association was organized. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The name and address of each member of the association. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The names of the initial members of the board of trustees and the name of the initial associationï¿½s administrator. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Such other information as the Commissioner may require. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The application must be accompanied by: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A nonrefundable filing fee of $1,000 and, in addition to any other fee or charge, all applicable fees required pursuant toNRS 680C.110. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Proof of compliance withNRS 616B.353. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Proof that the association or its third-party administrator is licensed or otherwise authorized to conduct business in this State pursuant to title 57 of NRS. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A copy of the agreements entered into with the associationï¿½s administrator and a third-party administrator. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A copy of the bylaws of the association. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A copy of an agreement jointly and severally binding the association and each member of the association to secure the payment of all compensation due pursuant tochapters 616Ato617, inclusive, of NRS. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A pro forma financial statement prepared by an independent certified public accountant in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles that shows the financial ability of the association to pay all compensation due pursuant tochapters 616Ato617, inclusive, of NRS. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A reviewed financial statement prepared by an independent certified public accountant for each proposed member of the association or evidence of the ability of the association or its proposed members to provide a solvency bond pursuant to subsection 3 ofNRS 616B.353. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Proof that each member of the association will make the initial payment to the association required pursuant toNRS 616B.416on a date specified by the Commissioner. The payment shall be deemed to be a part of the assessment required to be paid by each member for the first year of self-insurance if certification is issued to the association. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided inNRS 239.0115, any financial information relating to a member of an association received by the Commissioner pursuant to the provisions of this section is confidential and must not be disclosed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
For the purposes of this section, ï¿½associate member of a bona fide trade associationï¿½ means a supplier whose business, as determined by the Commissioner: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is limited to a specific industry; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Primarily involves providing a product or service that is directly used or consumed by substantially all of the members of the trade association or bears a direct relationship to the business of the members of the association.

section.heading: Indemnity agreement; policy of excess insurance; assessment; bond or similar security; minimum combined tangible net worth; combined net cash flows; bond required of associationï¿½s administrator or third-party administrator; Account for Associations of Self-Insured Public and Private Employers.

content.p: An association of self-insured public or private employers shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Execute an indemnity agreement jointly and severally binding the association and each member of the association to secure the payment of all compensation due pursuant tochapters 616Ato617, inclusive, of NRS. The indemnity agreement must be in a form prescribed by the Commissioner. An association may add provisions to the indemnity agreement if they are first approved by the Commissioner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, maintain a policy of specific and aggregate excess insurance in a form and amount required by the Commissioner. The excess insurance must be written by an insurer approved by the Commissioner. To determine the amount of excess insurance required, the Commissioner shall consider: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the association is an association of self-insured public employers, the types of governmental services provided by the members of the association; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the association is an association of self-insured private employers, the classifications of employment of the members of the association; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The number of years the association has been in existence; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Such other information as the Commissioner deems necessary. ï¿½Nothing in this paragraph prohibits an association from purchasing secondary excess insurance in addition to the excess insurance required by this paragraph. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Collect an annual assessment from each member of the association in an aggregate amount of at least $250,000 or in an aggregate amount which the Commissioner determines is satisfactory based on an annual review conducted by the Commissioner of the actuarial solvency of the association. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Except as otherwise provided in paragraph

, deposit as security with the Commissioner a bond executed by the association as principal, and by a licensed surety, payable to the State of Nevada, and conditioned upon the payment of compensation for injuries and occupational diseases to their employees. The bond must be in an amount determined by the Commissioner to be reasonably sufficient to ensure payment of such compensation, but in no event may it be less than $100,000. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In lieu of a bond, deposit with the Commissioner a like amount of lawful money of the United States or any other form of security authorized byNRS 100.065. If security is provided in the form of a savings certificate, certificate of deposit or investment certificate, the certificate must state that the amount is unavailable for withdrawal except upon order of the Commissioner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Except as otherwise provided in subsection 3, in addition to complying with the requirements of subsection 1, an association of self-insured private employers shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

At the time of initial qualification and until the association has operated successfully as a qualified association of self-insured private employers for 3 years, as determined by the Commissioner, have a combined tangible net worth of all members in the association of at least $2,500,000, as evidenced by a statement of tangible net worth provided to the Division of Insurance of the Department of Business and Industry by an independent certified public accountant; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

After 3 years of successful operation as a qualified association of self-insured private employers, as determined by the Commissioner, have combined net cash flows from operating activities plus net cash flows from financing activities of all members in the association of five times the average of claims paid for each of the last 3 years or $7,500,000, whichever is less. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In lieu of complying with the requirements of subsection 2, the associationï¿½s administrator shall ensure that a solvency bond, in a form prescribed by the Commissioner and in an aggregate amount of at least $2,500,000, is deposited with the Commissioner by the association or members of the association on behalf of the association. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The associationï¿½s administrator shall deposit with the Commissioner a bond executed by the associationï¿½s administrator as principal, and by a licensed surety, payable to the State of Nevada, and conditioned upon the faithful performance of his or her duties. The bond must be in an amount determined by the Commissioner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any third-party administrator providing claims services for the association shall deposit with the Commissioner a bond executed by the third-party administrator as principal, and by a licensed surety, payable to the State of Nevada, and conditioned upon the faithful performance of its duties. The bond must be in an amount determined by the Commissioner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Commissioner may increase or decrease the amount of any bond or money required to be deposited by this section in accordance withchapter 681Bof NRS and the Commissionerï¿½s regulations for loss reserves in casualty insurance. If the Commissioner requires an association, associationï¿½s administrator or third-party administrator to increase its deposit, the Commissioner may specify the form of the additional security. The association, associationï¿½s administrator or third-party administrator shall comply with such a requirement within 60 days after receiving notice from the Commissioner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Account for Associations of Self-Insured Public and Private Employers is hereby created in the State Agency Fund for Bonds. All money received by the Commissioner pursuant to this section must be deposited with the State Treasurer to the credit of the Account. All claims against this Account must be paid as other claims against the State are paid.

section.heading: Certificate of authority required before surety or bonding company may furnish bond or other security for association.

content.p: A surety or bonding company shall not furnish a bond or any other form of security required by the provisions ofchapters 616Ato616D, inclusive, or chapter617of NRS for an association of self-insured public or private employers or a member of such an association unless the surety or bonding company holds a certificate of authority issued by the Commissioner.

section.heading: Certificate of qualification as an association of self-insured employers: Time for consideration of application; issuance by Commissioner; contents; effective date; period certificate is in effect; cancellation by association.

content.p: The Commissioner shall grant or deny an application for certification as an association of self-insured public or private employers within 60 days after receiving the application. If the application is materially incomplete or does not comply with the applicable provisions of the law, the Commissioner shall notify the applicant of the additional information or changes required. Under such circumstances, if the Commissioner is unable to act upon the application within this 60-day period, the Commissioner may extend the period for granting or denying the application, but for not longer than an additional 90 days. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Upon determining that an association is qualified as an association of self-insured public or private employers, the Commissioner shall issue a certificate to that effect to the association and the associationï¿½s administrator. No certificate may be issued to an association that, within the 2 years immediately preceding its application, has had its certification as an association of self-insured public or private employers involuntarily withdrawn by the Commissioner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A certificate issued pursuant to this section must include, without limitation: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The name of the association; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The name of each employer who the Commissioner determines is a member of the association at the time of the issuance of the certificate; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An identification number assigned to the association by the Commissioner; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The date on which the certificate was issued. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A certificate issued pursuant to this section remains in effect until the certificate is withdrawn by the Commissioner, the certificate is cancelled at the request of the association or an association does not pay, in addition to any other fee or charge, all applicable fees required pursuant toNRS 680C.110. Coverage for an association granted a certificate becomes effective on the date of certification or the date specified in the certificate. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Commissioner shall not grant a request to cancel a certificate unless the association has insured or reinsured all incurred obligations with an insurer authorized to do business in this State pursuant to an agreement filed with and approved by the Commissioner. The agreement must include coverage for actual claims and claims incurred but not reported, and the expenses associated with those claims.

section.heading: Effect of certification; responsibility of association to provide compensation and administer claims.

content.p: An association certified as an association of self-insured public or private employers directly assumes the responsibility for providing compensation due the employees of the members of the association and their beneficiaries underchapters 616Ato617, inclusive, of NRS. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An association is not required to pay the premiums required of other employers pursuant tochapters 616Ato617, inclusive, of NRS but is relieved from other liability for personal injury to the same extent as are other employers. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The claims of employees and their beneficiaries resulting from injuries while in the employment of a member of an association must be handled in the manner provided bychapters 616Ato616D, inclusive, of NRS, and the association is subject to the regulations of the Division with respect thereto. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The security deposited pursuant toNRS 616B.353does not relieve an association from responsibility for the administration of claims and payment of compensation underchapters 616Ato617, inclusive, of NRS.

section.heading: Board of trustees: Members; duties; prohibited acts.

content.p: An association of self-insured public or private employers must be operated by a board of trustees consisting of at least five members whom the members of the association elect for terms set forth in the bylaws of the association. If the association is an association of self-insured: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Public employers, the members of the board of trustees must be officers or employees of the public employers who are members of the association. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Private employers, at least two-thirds of the members of the board of trustees must be employees, officers or directors of the members of the association. No associationï¿½s administrator or third-party administrator employed by the association, or any owner, officer, employee or other person affiliated with the associationï¿½s administrator or third-party administrator, may serve as a member of the board of trustees. Each member of the board of trustees must be a resident of this State or an officer of a corporation authorized to do business in this State. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The board of trustees of an association shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Ensure the prompt payment of any compensation due pursuant tochapters 616Ato616D, inclusive, or chapter617of NRS. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Take such actions as are necessary to protect the assets of the association. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Employ full-time an associationï¿½s administrator to carry out the policies of the board of trustees and perform such duties as the board delegates to him or her. An associationï¿½s administrator shall not perform any of the duties assigned to a third-party administrator. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Employ a third-party administrator to carry out the duties set forth inNRS 616B.503. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Employ an independent certified public accountant to prepare the statement of financial condition required byNRS 616B.404. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Maintain minutes of its meetings and make the minutes available for inspection by the Commissioner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The board of trustees of an association shall not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Extend credit to any member of the association for the payment of that memberï¿½s annual assessment, except pursuant to a payment plan approved by the Commissioner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Borrow any money from the association or in the name of the association, except in the ordinary course of its business, without the prior approval of the Commissioner.

section.heading: Board of trustees: Fiscal responsibilities; establishment of accounts; review of accounts by Commissioner.

content.p: The board of trustees of an association of self-insured public or private employers is responsible for the money collected and disbursed by the association. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The board of trustees shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Establish a claims account in a financial institution in this State which is approved by the Commissioner and which is federally insured or insured by a private insurer approved pursuant toNRS 672.755. Except as otherwise provided in subsection 3, at least 75 percent of the annual assessment collected by the association from its members must be deposited in this account to pay: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Claims; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Expenses related to those claims; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The costs associated with the associationï¿½s policy of excess insurance; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Assessments, payments and penalties related to the Subsequent Injury Account and the Uninsured Employersï¿½ Claim Account. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Establish an administrative account in a financial institution in this State which is approved by the Commissioner and which is federally insured or insured by a private insurer approved pursuant toNRS 672.755. The amount of the annual assessment collected by the association that is not deposited in its claims account must be deposited in this account to pay the administrative expenses of the association. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Commissioner may authorize an association to deposit less than 75 percent of its annual assessment in its claims account if the association presents evidence to the satisfaction of the Commissioner that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
More than 25 percent of the associationï¿½s annual assessment is needed to maintain its programs for loss control and occupational safety; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The associationï¿½s policy of excess insurance attaches at less than 75 percent. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The board of trustees may invest the money of the association not needed to pay the obligations of the association pursuant tochapter 682Aof NRS. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Commissioner shall review the accounts of an association established pursuant to this section at such times as the Commissioner deems necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this section.

section.heading: Associationï¿½s administrator prohibited from financial interest in third-party administrator; third-party administrator prohibited from financial interest in associationï¿½s administrator; contractual requirement.

content.p: An associationï¿½s administrator employed by an association of self-insured public or private employers, or an employee, officer or director of an associationï¿½s administrator, may not be an employee, officer or director of a third-party administrator employed by the association or have a direct or indirect financial interest in the third-party administrator of the association. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The third-party administrator of an association of self-insured public or private employers, or an employee, officer or director of the third-party administrator, may not be an employee, officer or director of an associationï¿½s administrator employed by the association or have a direct or indirect financial interest in that associationï¿½s administrator. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any contract entered into by an association of self-insured public or private employers and a third-party administrator must include a provision which states that, unless the Commissioner otherwise provides, the third-party administrator shall administer any claim or other obligation of the association to its conclusion during the period of the contract.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (Added to NRS by1993, 673; A1995, 1982)—(Substituted in revision for NRS 616.3793)

section.heading: Solicitorï¿½s permit: Advertising or offering for sale membership in proposed association of self-insured public or private employers without permit prohibited; application for permit; fee; penalty; exceptions.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in this section, a person shall not advertise or offer for sale in this State any policies or memberships or solicit or receive any money, subscriptions, applications, premiums, assessments, memberships or any other fee or charge in connection with a proposed association of self-insured public or private employers unless the person has obtained a solicitorï¿½s permit from the Commissioner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To obtain a solicitorï¿½s permit, a person must file a written application with the Commissioner. The application must include: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

On forms furnished by the Commissioner, for each person associated or to be associated as director, promoter, manager, member of the board or in another similar capacity in the association, or in the formation of the proposed association or in the proposed financing: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
His or her business, professional or employment experience for the preceding 10 years; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A complete set of his or her fingerprints which the Commissioner may forward to the Central Repository for Nevada Records of Criminal History for submission to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for its report; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A full disclosure of the terms of all pertinent understandings and agreements existing or proposed among any persons or entities so associated or to be associated, and a copy of each such agreement; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The plan according to which solicitations are to be made and a reasonably detailed estimate of all administrative and sales expenses to be incurred; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Proof of an escrow account and agreement for the deposit of all funds collected during the formation of the association; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Such additional pertinent information as the Commissioner may reasonably require. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The application must be accompanied by a fee of $500 for the filing of the application and for the issuance of the permit, if granted. A solicitor must submit this fee each year thereafter if the solicitor continues to recruit new members for an association. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who violates subsection 1 is guilty of a category D felony and shall be punished as provided inNRS 193.130. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provisions of this section do not apply to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A bona fide trade association that has been in existence for at least 5 years and solicits members of its trade association; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who is employed by: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Current members of an association; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Employers that are considering membership in an association, ï¿½whose primary duties do not include solicitation of potential members of the association.

section.heading: Solicitorï¿½s permit: Commissioner to conduct investigation after filing of application for permit; required issuance of permit; Commissioner to give notice to applicant if application denied; fee nonrefundable.

content.p: After the filing of an application for a solicitorï¿½s permit, the Commissioner shall promptly cause an investigation to be made of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The identity, character, reputation, experience, financial standing and motives of the persons proposing to organize, promote or finance the association of self-insured public or private employers; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The character, financial responsibility, management experience and business qualifications of the officers, directors and managers of the existing or proposed association; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any other aspects of the solicitor, association or proposed financing as the Commissioner deems advisable. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Commissioner shall expeditiously examine an application for a solicitorï¿½s permit and complete the investigation required pursuant to subsection 1. Except as otherwise provided in subsection 3, if the Commissioner finds after performing an examination and investigation that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The documents filed with the application are proper in form; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The proposed financing is reasonable and adequate in amount for the purposes intended and the applicant is otherwise entitled to the permit, ï¿½the Commissioner shall issue a permit and assign a permit number to the applicant. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the Commissioner does not so find, or finds that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any of the persons associated or to be associated with the association are not of good reputation as to business affairs or financial responsibility; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

There is material variance, adverse to the applicant, as between the information furnished by the applicant in connection with the application and that determined by the Commissioner on investigation, ï¿½the Commissioner shall give notice to the applicant that a permit will not be granted, stating the particulars of the grounds for the denial. The Commissioner shall not refund the fee for the filing of the application.

section.heading: Solicitorï¿½s permit: Power of Commissioner to suspend or revoke permit; hearing required.

content.p: The Commissioner may suspend or revoke a solicitorï¿½s permit if the Commissioner reasonably believes that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A violation of this chapter orchapter 616A,616C,616Dor617of NRS or title 57 of NRS or the terms of the permit or any proper order of the Commissioner has occurred; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A material misrepresentation in the offering or sale of securities, policies or memberships pursuant to the permit has occurred. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the Commissioner suspends or revokes a permit pursuant to subsection 1, the Commissioner shall expeditiously conduct a hearing, giving the holder of the permit a reasonable opportunity to appear and be heard.

section.heading: Advertisements or written materials to join association of self-insured public or private employers; solicitor to provide to Commissioner upon request copy of document relating to solicitation.

content.p: Any advertising or written material that solicits employers to join an association of self-insured public or private employers must contain the permit number of the solicitor. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A solicitor shall provide to the Commissioner upon request a copy of any document relating to a solicitation which was prepared after the solicitor filed his or her application for a permit.

section.heading: Membership in association: Application; eligibility; authority of association to determine eligibility; termination by member; cancellation by association; information to be provided to Commissioner; provision of compensation after membership has ceased.

content.p: If an employer wishes to become a member of an association of self-insured public or private employers, the employer must: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Submit an application for membership to the board of trustees or third-party administrator of the association; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Enter into an indemnity agreement as required byNRS 616B.353. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The membership of the applicant becomes effective when each member of the association approves the application or on a later date specified by the association. The application for membership and the action taken on the application must be maintained as permanent records of the board of trustees. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Each member who is a member of an association during the 12 months immediately following the formation of the association must: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Have a tangible net worth of at least $500,000; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Have had a reported payroll for the previous 12 months which would have resulted in a manual premium of at least $15,000, calculated in accordance with a manual prepared pursuant to subsection 4 ofNRS 686B.1765. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An employer who seeks to become a member of the association after the 12 months immediately following the formation of the association must meet the requirement set forth in paragraph
or

An association of self-insured private employers may apply to the Commissioner for authority to determine the documentation demonstrating solvency that an employer must provide to become a member of the association. The Commissioner shall approve the application if the association: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has been certified to act as an association for at least the 3 consecutive years immediately preceding the date on which the association filed the application with the Commissioner; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has, as determined by the Commissioner, either: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A combined tangible net worth of all members in the association of at least $5,000,000; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Combined net cash flows from operating activities plus net cash flows from financing activities of all members in the association of five times the average of claims paid for each of the last 3 years or $7,500,000, whichever is less; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has at least 15 members. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Commissioner may withdraw approval of an application submitted pursuant to subsection 5 or 6 if the Commissioner determines the association has ceased to comply with any of the requirements set forth in subsection 5 or 6, as applicable. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

, unless the association first receives notice from the Administrator that the member has: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a member of an association changes his or her name or form of organization, the member remains liable for any obligations incurred or any responsibilities imposed pursuant tochapters 616Ato617, inclusive, of NRS under the memberï¿½s former name or form of organization. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

section.heading: Provision of member information upon request.

content.p: If a member of an association of self-insured public or private employers requests, in writing, information required for the memberï¿½s certificate of insurance, the association shall, within 30 days after receiving the request, provide to the member information regarding claims paid and reserves for claims incurred that are maintained on behalf of the member.

section.heading: Notification of Commissioner required if change in information submitted for certification.

content.p: An association of self-insured public or private employers shall notify the Commissioner of any change in the information submitted in its application for certification or in the manner of its compliance withNRS 616B.353not later than 30 days after the change. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

For the purposes of this section, the addition of an employer to the membership of an association of self-insured private employers is not a change in the information that the association submitted in its application for certification.

section.heading: Examination of books, records, accounts and assets of association by Commissioner; payment of related expenses.

content.p: The Commissioner may examine the books, records, accounts and assets of an association of self-insured public or private employers as the Commissioner deems necessary to carry out the provisions ofNRS 616B.350to616B.446, inclusive. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The expense of any examination conducted pursuant to this section must be paid by the association.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (Added to NRS by1993, 675)—(Substituted in revision for NRS 616.3794)

section.heading: Commissioner is attorney-in-fact of association for receipt of initial legal process.

content.p: An association of self-insured public or private employers shall be deemed to have appointed the Commissioner as its attorney-in-fact to receive any initial legal process authorized by law to be served upon the association for as long as the association is obligated to pay any compensation underchapters 616Ato616D, inclusive, or chapter617of NRS. Service of process against an association for whom the Commissioner is attorney-in-fact must be made in accordance withNRS 680A.260.

section.heading: Merger of associations.

content.p: An association of self-insured public employers may merge with another association of self-insured public employers if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The resulting association assumes in full all obligations of the merging associations; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The merger is approved by the Commissioner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An association of self-insured private employers may merge with another association of self-insured private employers if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The resulting association assumes in full all obligations of the merging associations; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The merger is approved by the Commissioner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Commissioner shall conduct a hearing on the proposed merger if any member of the merging associations so requests. The Commissioner may on his or her own motion conduct such a hearing.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (Added to NRS by1993, 675; A1995, 1984)—(Substituted in revision for NRS 616.37947)

section.heading: Statement of financial condition: Filing dates; contents; form; additional reports.

content.p: An association of self-insured public or private employers shall file with the Commissioner an audited statement of financial condition prepared by an independent certified public accountant. The statement must be filed on or before May 1 of each year or within 120 days after the conclusion of the associationï¿½s fiscal year and must contain information for the previous fiscal year. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The statement required by subsection 1 must be in a form prescribed by the Commissioner and include, without limitation: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A statement of the reserves for: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Actual claims and expenses; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Assessments that are due, but not paid; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Unpaid debts, which must be shown as liabilities. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An actuarial opinion regarding reserves that is prepared by a member of the American Academy of Actuaries or another specialist in loss reserves identified in the annual statement adopted by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners. The actuarial opinion must include a statement of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Actual claims and the expenses associated with those claims; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Claims incurred but not reported, and the expenses associated with those claims. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Commissioner may adopt a uniform financial reporting system for associations of self-insured public and private employers to ensure the accurate and complete reporting of financial information. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Commissioner may require the filing of such other reports as the Commissioner deems necessary to carry out the provisions of this section, including, without limitation: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Reports of losses; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Quarterly financial statements.

section.heading: Calculation of annual assessment paid by each member of association.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, the annual assessment required to be paid by each member of an association of self-insured public or private employers must be: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Calculated by a rate service organization that is licensed pursuant tochapter 686Bof NRS; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Based on the premium rate for the standard industrial classification of that member, adjusted by the memberï¿½s individual experience. ï¿½If approved by the Commissioner, payments of assessments may be reduced by an amount based on the associationï¿½s level of expenses and loss experience. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If approved by the Commissioner, an association may calculate the annual assessment required to be paid by each member of the association. An assessment calculated by the association must be based on at least 5 years of the memberï¿½s individual experience.

section.heading: Annual audits; objection to assignment of standard industrial classification.

content.p: The Commissioner shall cause to be conducted at least annually an audit of each association of self-insured public or private employers in order to verify: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The payroll of each member of the association; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The assessment required to be paid by each member of the association. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The audit required by this section must be conducted by an auditor approved by the Commissioner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A report of the audit must be filed with the Commissioner in a form required by the Commissioner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The association or any member of the association may request a hearing before the Commissioner to object to any standard industrial classification assigned to a member of the association as a result of the audit. If the Commissioner determines that the assessment required to be paid by any member of the association is: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Insufficient because of the standard industrial classification assigned to the member, the Commissioner shall order the association to collect from that member any amount required to recover the deficiency. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Excessive because of the standard industrial classification assigned to the member, the Commissioner shall order the association to pay to the member the excess amount collected. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The expenses of any audit conducted pursuant to this section must be paid by the association.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (Added to NRS by1993, 676)—(Substituted in revision for NRS 616.37957)

section.heading: Payment of dividends to members of association.

content.p: If the assets of an association of self-insured public or private employers exceed the amount necessary for the association to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Carry reasonable reserves; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Provide for contingencies, ï¿½the board of trustees of the association may, after obtaining the approval of the Commissioner, declare and distribute dividends to the members of the association. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any dividend declared pursuant to subsection 1 must be distributed not less than 12 months after the end of the fund year. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A dividend may be paid only to those members who are members of the association for the entire fund year. The payment of a dividend must not be conditioned upon the member continuing his or her membership in the association after the fund year. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An association shall give to each prospective member of the association a written description of its plan for distributing dividends when the prospective member applies for membership in the association.

section.heading: Plan for payment of annual assessments by members of association.

content.p: Each association of self-insured public or private employers shall adopt a plan for the payment of annual assessments by the members of the association which must be approved by the Commissioner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An initial payment, in advance, of a portion of the annual assessment due from each member of the association. If the association is an association of self-insured private employers, the initial payment must be in an amount equal to at least 25 percent of the memberï¿½s annual assessment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Payment of the balance of the annual assessment due in quarterly or monthly installments.

section.heading: Required reserves.

content.p: Actuarially appropriate loss reserves. Such reserves must include reserves for: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Actual claims and the expenses associated with those claims; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Claims incurred but not reported, and the expenses associated with those claims. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Reserves for uncollected debts based on the experience of the association or other associations.

section.heading: Insufficient assets to pay compensation due and maintain reserves.

content.p: If the assets of an association of self-insured public or private employers are insufficient to make certain the prompt payment of all compensation underchapters 616Ato617, inclusive, of NRS and to maintain the reserves required byNRS 616B.419, the association shall immediately notify the Commissioner of the deficiency and: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Collect an additional assessment from its members in an amount required to make up the deficiency; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Take any other action to make up the deficiency which is approved by the Commissioner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the association wishes to transfer any surplus from one fund year to another, the association must first notify the Commissioner of the transfer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Commissioner shall order the association to make up any deficiency pursuant to subsection 1 if the association fails to do so within 30 days after notifying the Commissioner of the deficiency. The association shall be deemed insolvent if it fails to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
